articles.headline: Climate Is Big Issue for Hispanics, and Personal
articles.snippet: Hispanics are more likely than whites to view global warming as a problem that affects them personally and to support policies aimed at curbing it, a New York Times poll has found.
articles.abstract: Hispanics are more likely than whites to view global warming as a problem that affects them personally and to support policies aimed at curbing it, a New York Times poll has found.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Alfredo Padilla grew up in Texas as a migrant farmworker who followed the harvest with his parents to pick sugar beets in Minnesota each summer. He has not forgotten the aches of labor or how much the weather — too little rain, or too much — affected the family livelihood.

articles.headline: Ruble’s Fall Tests Governor of Russia’s Central Bank
articles.snippet: Elvira S. Nabiullina, governor of the Bank of Russia, views the ruble’s steep drop as a painful but necessary step to wean the nation off imports.
articles.abstract: Elvira S. Nabiullina, governor of the Bank of Russia, views the ruble’s steep drop as a painful but necessary step to wean the nation off imports.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Elvira S. Nabiullina, the governor of Russia’s central bank, was deep into a speech about her new currency policy when it became clear nobody was paying attention.

articles.headline: China Hits Qualcomm With Fine
articles.snippet: In addition to the $975 million penalty, a record for the country, the chip maker agreed to sharply reduce the royalties it charges Chinese smartphone makers.
articles.abstract: In addition to the $975 million penalty, a record for the country, the chip maker agreed to sharply reduce the royalties it charges Chinese smartphone makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In the last decade, foreign technology companies have plowed billions into China in the hopes of tapping into a fast-growing market. Now that the country has the world’s most Internet users and its largest smartphone market, multinationals are bumping into a regulatory ceiling.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Quentin Hardy

articles.headline: Left and Right Align in Fighting Obama’s Trade Agenda
articles.snippet: The White House has some unlikely allies in the president’s plans for international trade.
articles.abstract: The White House has some unlikely allies in the president’s plans for international trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An odd marriage of convenience between liberal Democrats and Tea Party Republicans is squeezing President Obama on his ambitious trade agenda, forcing the White House and top Republicans to fight a two-front war on an international economic effort the president hopes to secure before he leaves office.

articles.headline: Do Activist Investors Target Female C.E.O.s?
articles.snippet: Only 23 women lead companies in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index. Yet at least a quarter of them have fallen into the cross hairs of activist investors.
articles.abstract: Only 23 women lead companies in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index. Yet at least a quarter of them have fallen into the cross hairs of activist investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Indra K. Nooyi. Marissa Mayer. Ellen J. Kullman. Irene B. Rosenfeld. Meg Whitman. Mary T. Barra.

articles.headline: Illinois Governor Acts to Curb Power of Public Sector Unions
articles.snippet: Gov. Bruce Rauner’s executive order would ban unions from requiring all state workers to pay the equivalent of dues.
articles.abstract: Gov. Bruce Rauner’s executive order would ban unions from requiring all state workers to pay the equivalent of dues.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Gov. Bruce Rauner, the newly elected Republican who has often criticized public sector unions, took his first step toward curbing their power on Monday by announcing an executive order that would bar unions from requiring all state workers to pay the equivalent of dues.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Justice Department Is Seeking Felony Pleas by Big Banks in Foreign Currency Inquiry
articles.snippet: The Justice Department is demanding that some of Wall Street’s biggest banks plead guilty to criminal charges in order to settle a long-running investigation.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department is demanding that some of Wall Street’s biggest banks plead guilty to criminal charges in order to settle a long-running investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is pushing some of the biggest banks on Wall Street — including, for the first time in decades, American institutions — to plead guilty to criminal charges that they manipulated the prices of foreign currencies.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: A Biofuel Debate: Will Cutting Trees Cut Carbon?
articles.snippet: Governments across the world are incorporating bioenergy into transportation fuels, hoping to limit dependence on gasoline. But not everyone is convinced it’s a good idea.
articles.abstract: Governments across the world are incorporating bioenergy into transportation fuels, hoping to limit dependence on gasoline. But not everyone is convinced it’s a good idea.
articles.lead_paragraph: Does combating climate change require burning the world’s forests and crops for fuel?

articles.headline: Amy Pascal Keeps Sony’s Marquee Projects in Portfolio, Now as a Producer
articles.snippet: Ms. Pascal recently said she would step down from major roles at Sony Pictures in the fallout over its hacking scandal, but she will produce some important film properties.
articles.abstract: Ms. Pascal recently said she would step down from major roles at Sony Pictures in the fallout over its hacking scandal, but she will produce some important film properties.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Amy Pascal may be giving up the Sony Pictures crown, but she’s keeping the jewels.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Hedge Fund-Backed Investor Puts Himself Up for G.M. Board
articles.snippet: A former member of the Obama administration’s auto task force, Harry J. Wilson, has teamed up with big hedge funds to seek a seat on the automaker’s board.
articles.abstract: A former member of the Obama administration’s auto task force, Harry J. Wilson, has teamed up with big hedge funds to seek a seat on the automaker’s board.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six years ago, Harry J. Wilson was enlisted by the Obama administration to help overhaul General Motors as part of a taxpayer-financed bailout.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Bill Vlasic
